perturbation.original_text: 5. "Intellectual Property Rights" means all rights in and to (a) U.S. and foreign patents and patent applications, including all divisions, substitutions, continuations, continuations-in-part, and any reissues, re-examinations and extensions thereof, (b) copyrights and other rights in works of authorship, (c) unpatented inventions, trade secrets, data, processes, or materials, (d) mask work rights, and (e) other intellectual property or proprietary rights of any kind now known or hereafter recognized in any jurisdiction, but excluding trademarks, service marks, trade names, trade dress, domain names, logos and similar rights, and the goodwill associated therewith.
perturbation.changed_text: 5. "Intellectual Property Rights" means all rights in and to (a) U.S. and foreign patents and patent applications, including all divisions, substitutions, continuations, continuations-in-part, and any reissues, re-examinations and extensions thereof, (b) copyrights and other rights in works of authorship, (c) unpatented inventions, trade secrets, data, processes, or materials, (d) mask work rights, and (e) other intellectual property or proprietary rights of any kind now known or hereafter recognized in any jurisdiction, including trademarks, service marks, trade names, trade dress, domain names, logos and similar rights, and the goodwill associated therewith.
perturbation.explanation: The original definition of Intellectual Property Rights explicitly excludes trademarks. This change includes trademarks, creating a direct contradiction. This impacts indemnification clauses and other sections where intellectual property is referenced, making it unclear whether trademark disputes are covered.

perturbation.original_text: 12. "Purchase Order" means any of the following (a) a written purchase order issued to the Company by third party buyers for the purchase of certain Products; (b) a written purchase order issued by the Company to a Supplier for a quantity of the Product.
perturbation.changed_text: 12. "Purchase Order" means a written purchase order issued to the Company by third party buyers for the purchase of certain Products. Purchase orders issued by the Company to a Supplier for a quantity of the Product are termed 'Internal Requisitions'.
perturbation.explanation: The original definition includes both customer and internal orders under the same term. This change explicitly distinguishes between customer purchase orders and internal orders, calling the latter 'Internal Requisitions.' This creates confusion because other sections of the agreement refer to 'Purchase Orders' related to obligations between the company and suppliers; thus the obligations could potentially be ignored, deeming them as not purchase orders but internal requisitions.

perturbation.original_text: 6.1 Suppliers Limited Warranty   Each of the Suppliers warrants that the Products shall comply with the specifications and documentation agreed by the relevant Supplier and the Company in writing that is applicable to such Products for the Warranty Period. This warranty does not apply to any Product failures resulting from misuse, storage in or exposure to environmental conditions inconsistent with those specified in the applicable specifications or documentation, modification of the Product by anyone other than the relevant Supplier. If a Product fails to comply with the foregoing warranty, the relevant Supplier shall, at its option, either [***]such Product, or, in the event the foregoing options are not commercially practicable, [***]to the Company any amounts paid for the applicable Product. Without limiting the remedies specified in Article 8 and Section 9.2, this Section 6.1 states the exclusive remedy of the Company for failure of a Product to conform to the warranty provisions set forth in this Section 6.1.
perturbation.changed_text: 6.1 Suppliers Limited Warranty   Each of the Suppliers warrants that the Products shall comply with the specifications and documentation agreed by the relevant Supplier and the Company in writing that is applicable to such Products for a period of 30 days from delivery. This warranty only covers manufacturing defects discovered upon initial inspection. If a Product fails to comply with the foregoing warranty, the relevant Supplier shall, at its option, either [***]such Product, or, in the event the foregoing options are not commercially practicable, [***]to the Company any amounts paid for the applicable Product. Without limiting the remedies specified in Article 8 and Section 9.2, this Section 6.1 states the exclusive remedy of the Company for failure of a Product to conform to the warranty provisions set forth in this Section 6.1.
perturbation.explanation: The original text refers to 'Warranty Period' which is later defined in Schedule 1, Paragraph 13 as '[***]from the relevant Supplier's shipment of the Product.' This modification limits the warranty to 30 days from delivery and only covers manufacturing defects discovered upon initial inspection, adding an inspection requirement and reducing the time period of warranty coverage that contradicts the original definition.
